content.description: Grab the obvious jugs in the crack pull up for a good crimp and grab the undercling in the crack. Reach up high for the top then go left for the top out.
content.location: Left of Darkstar left of the big tree

content.description: Start as for Vigilante which some call the Warm Up Crack.  Get off the ground and where the crack turns left head straight up and onto the slab above.  The holds are not obvious from the ground and will most likely have no chalk but they will appear upon closer inspection.
content.location: Front side of Warm Up boulder in the Prow Area.  Begins on obvious crack.

content.description: Start with hands high in crack and step up. Follow crack as it tends left and finish on good holds and slab.
content.protection: A few pads to protect traverse or an attentive spotter.
content.location: Front side (downhill facing) of large boulder you come to when entering the Prow area. Ten feet right of Tackle Box.

content.description:
Testicules climbs the blunt right arete on the main face of the Warm Up boulder of the Prow area. Begin by pulling onto a large foot with a small left crimp and the right hand squeezing nothing around the blunt corner. A right heel in this same blank, chalky spot will allow both hands to move into a crimpy seam around the left side of the feature. Delicately transition to slopers at the lip, then snag the incut hold. Pull onto the slab and topout. You may want to scope the topout slab before trying. A cold weather problem.

 Testicules is a Gretna classic with great movement. It can be frustrating until one figures out the subtleties. I believe that name may stem from a combination of testicles and Hercules.
content.protection: Pads and a spotter.  There is a rock around the right that I've landed on precariously before.
content.location: Blunt right arete on the main face of the Warm Up boulder.

content.description: Follow large crack traversing left a few moves before moving up on large holds to top. A good cool down or part of an endurance circuit with other area problems.
content.location: Left side of large boulder. Obvious hand crack you come to when first entering the Prow area.

content.description:
Jutting out into the air like a ship's bow, enshrouded in mystery by the cryptic elephant skin diabase texture like a vessel in the mist, sits The Prow.  Technical, physical, involved and committing, this problem embodies everything of Mount Gretna and the rock type.  The sit start to the Prow is my all time favorite diabase boulder problem out of all areas in Pennsylvania, a state I was born in and never left until the age of 20.  I grew up on Mount Gretna Road, just a ten minute drive from the main boulder field.  I have a special connection with this problem. The stand start at a stiff V5 was one of my first V5's.  I completed the sit start to The Prow on April 1, 2003.  I remember that day vividly.  It was one of the first advanced boulder problems I had ever completed, both mentally and physically.  It took me probably 7 to 10 visits to do the stand start, and by the time I was working the sit start full line a season later I was doing the stand three to five times in a day in preparation. 

  I understand that now a hold has broken and it is most certainly the crucial left hand half pad three finger sidepull crimp that has enlarged.  The stand start is a sandbag or solid at the grade at V5.  Right hand up anywhere you want on the arete, scrunch up, and highstep onto the blade.  The right foot will be smearing on a downsloping feature, if it blows you will graze your shin on the underside of the roof.  A large deadpoint for a one pad left hand sidepull immediately follows.  It is the largest hold on the problem but is utilized for a very short period of time.  Delicately balance your way around the right arete after more slapping, 1/3 pad sidepulls and a high right foot smear.  There are at least three ways to get to the lip; technical and in control, shouldery and barndoorish, or all out dyno.  I prefer the former.   

  For the full V7 or V8 sit start line that nearly doubles the length and quality of the problem, start underneath the roof blade in a true sit start and work around left on solid, almost one pad crimps.  Make a very strenuous pull from a three finger three quarter pad left hand sidepull and grope up and right on the arete to a veiny pinch and swing both feet up and to the right.  It may help to be short on this sequence because it is so scrunchy.  High step like you would off of the ground to begin the stand start then execute the above.
content.protection: Multiple pads due to the real estate that needs to be covered rather than the height.  A spotter because barn-dooring is likely.  A crowd for moral support.
content.location: Top of the Prow/Warm Up area.

content.description: Definitely worth a mention in any conversation debating the best route at Gretna, and could stack up against any area classic anywhere.  Both the sit (V8) and the stand (V7) are amazing.  The sit used to be V9 but a hold broke and brought it down a grade. No matter how you start it the top is tricky and there are a few different ways to do it.  Whether you go with a heel hook, match, or all out dyno is up to you. No matter what you chose you'll be happy you stuck it.
content.protection: a few pads.  It's not a high ball but it's high enough and there's some spice at the top.  The landing area is nice and flat.
content.location: On the Prow Boulder.  Islander and The Prow share the same start.  Stay on the face for Islander, bust right around the arete for The Prow.  Do them both, they're rad!

content.description: Squat start with good holds and a decent chip for your left foot and big rail for right. Pull up to a gaston grab a crimp and reach for the top.
content.location: On the opposite back side of Serenity Crack under a tree in a small corridor

content.description: same start hold as IT, reach out right to crack. work your way out the crack to the lip. mantel on the lip and top out. keep feet to the left on IT. **right wall is off**.
Stand start and climb face to good hold at top.
content.location: Face left of large Tackle Box crack.

content.description: No beta spray here. Just a big offwidth/ squeeze chimney on clean rock that beckons to be climbed. Stand start on the microwave sized blocs in the back of the crack. Traverse out the crack to the jug and pull the lip.
content.location: Immediately right of the PROW. Stand start on the two blocks in the back of the offwidth.

content.description:
Getting to the Prow area involves a bit of a hike but its worth the effort.  The area offers some of Gretnas most inspiring lines and has quality problems across grades. Either hike straight in and warm up on the aptly named Warm Up Crack (V1) and Chets Children (V2) or project the area and send the classic Islander (V6) and Prow (V6).  While youre there be sure to check out the surprisingly good IT (V4) and crank out a few dozen laps on Serenity Crack(V0).  

  Most problems have good landings but a few wander so bring at least two pads.
